The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of therightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of therightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. Theopen formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visuallyimpaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of therightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. Theopen formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for thebenefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works andother subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate accessto published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copiesto visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of therightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons withdisabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distributeand make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EUlevel (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefitof people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distributeand make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EUlevel (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works andother subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate accessto published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Not educated with issue enough to leave a response. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people withaÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons withdisabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessibleformat copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

There are digitised versions of somematerials. However in the case of social studies and humanities, not all content is available digitally and some materials are out of print. The problem seems to be in the local copyright laws. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation ofthis (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of therightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons withdisabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefitof people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows forrather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. TheTreaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its MemberStates have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notablyby increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of therightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for anexception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦. Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people withaÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of works and other subject-matter for persons withdisabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works forpersons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible formatcopies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation for the benefit of people with aÂ disability.The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementationsat Member States level.At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibilityof works and other subject-matterforpersons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member Stateshave startedwork to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility to exchange accessible format copies across borders).

Directive 2001/29/ECprovides for an exception/limitation forthe benefit of people with aÂ disability. The open formulation of this (optional) provision allows for rather different implementations at Member States level. At EU and international level projects have been launched to increase the accessibility of worksand other subject-matter for persons with disabilities (notably by increasing the number of works published in special formats and facilitating their distribution across the European Union). The Marrakesh Treatyhas been adopted to facilitate access to published works for persons who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled. The Treaty creates a mandatory exception to copyright that allows organisations for the blind to produce, distribute and make available accessible format copies to visually impaired persons without the authorisation of the rightholders. The EU and its Member States have started work to sign and ratify the Treaty. This may require the adoption of certain provisions at EU level (e.g. to ensure the possibility toexchange accessible format copies across borders).
